I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Republic of the Maldives for the Inclusive Micro, Small, and 
Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Project.1 
 
2. 
The  project  will  promote  economic  inclusion  in  the  Maldives  by  bolstering  economic 
activities, including in remote islands, through more opportunities and access to finance for micro, 
small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs)  and  thereby  contribute  to  private  sector 
development  and  overall  economic  growth.  This  will  be  achieved  through  stronger  business 
development infrastructure, better access to market information, and broader access to finance.  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale  

 
A. 
 
3. 
The  Maldives  has  been  confronted  in  recent  years  with  several  challenges  that  had  a 
severe  impact  on  the  economy.  In  December  2004,  the  ravages  of  the  tsunami  destroyed,  in 
relative  terms,  a  higher  share  of  natural  infrastructure  in  the  Maldives  than  in  any  of  the  other 
stricken  economies.  In  2007,  the  country  was  mired  in  its  own  fiscal  crisis  linked  to  excessive 
spending and acute structural distortions in the economy, which was further compounded by the 
slowdown in tourism after the global crisis. In 2008, the Maldives managed a difficult transition to 
democracy,  which,  in  the  interim  and  given  the  resulting  uncertainty,  led  to  capital  outflow  and 
limited investment in the economy.   
 
While  much  effort  has  focused  on  rebuilding  the  economy,  the  government  is  now 
4. 
concentrating on the pursuit of more inclusive growth to rectify some pressing shortcomings such 
as the lack of economic opportunities outside of Malé and the skewed concentration of ―enclave‖ 
economic  activity  in  the  resorts-based  tourism  industry.  Political,  administrative,  and  economic 
decentralization will support this goal, and greater availability of credit is an important platform to 
promote financial inclusion and engender economic and employment opportunities. 
 
5. 
The  Maldives  has  an  overall  unemployment  rate  of  15.4%,  and  youth  unemployment  is 
even  higher  at  around  25%.  Income  disparities  between  Malé  and  the  atolls  are  large  and 
increasing.  The Gini coefficient  has  remained  almost constant  over  time  at  around  0.4,  which is 
notably  higher  than  that  in  neighboring  countries.  Over  time  inequality  between  Malé  and  the 
atolls has steadily increased. MSME development has been prioritized by the government as one 
of the key solutions toward fostering greater economic inclusion, and the lack of access to finance 
as the  most  significant  impediment  to  the  promotion  and  development  of  MSMEs.  As  part  of  its 
earlier  effort  to  support  inclusive  growth  through  private  sector  development,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  technical  assistance  loan  in  2008  for  the  Private  Sector 
Development Project (PSDP) to support MSMEs in the Maldives.2 
 
6. 
Achievements under the Private Sector Development Project. MSME development is 
part of the development strategy for the Maldives under the 7th National Plan, 2006–2010. Until 
2011, there was no official definition of MSMEs in the Maldives. Furthermore, the local banks had 
no  direction  or  guidelines  on  how  to  assist  MSMEs.  The  major  achievements  under  the  PSDP 
include (i) establishment of a central business development service center (BDSC) and two field

(v)  completion  of  business 

BDSCs; (ii) establishment of a cost-sharing facility (CSF) (SDR0.6 million), a line-of-credit facility 
(LCF)  (SDR1.8  million),  and  a  credit  information  bureau  (CIB),  and  a  feasibility  study  on  a 
centralized  movable  asset  registry  (now  referred  to  as  secured  transaction  registry  [STR]); 
(iii) provision of business counseling and mentoring for over 500 entrepreneurs; (iv) start-up of 55 
than 
new  MSMEs; 
4,000 beneficiaries,  41%  of  whom  were  women;  (vi)  launch  of  a  BDSC  web  portal  to  promote 
BDSC services and dissemination of information related to MSME registration and CSF and LCF 
application procedures; and (vii) public–private partnership (PPP) capacity building that included 
developing  a  PPP  framework  and  piloting  three  PPP  initiatives.  Around  60  MSMEs  in  fisheries, 
tourism, arts, and handicrafts have benefited from the LCF, which helped expand their business 
operations, develop their capacity for accessing finance from the banks, and formalize the MSME 
sector through registration.3 
 
Remaining  challenges.  The  success  of  the  PSDP 4  led  to  further  demand  from 
7. 
stakeholders  for  continued,  demonstration-based  support.  The  PSDP  resulted  in  the  market 
demanding  additional  and  more  sophisticated  business  development  services  (BDS).  Further 
work is needed to (i) improve the quality and depth of BDS on offer; (ii) add a range of new BDS; 
and  (iii)  expand  the  geographic  coverage  of  BDS  to  ensure  countrywide  availability.  Even 
conservative  assessments indicate  a large  unmet credit  demand  of  $15 million–$30 million from 
MSMEs. Despite the PSDP’s success in improving access to finance, considerable work remains 
to  be  done  to  bridge  this  gap.  Given  the  stringent  collateral  requirements  imposed  by  banks,  a 
mechanism for reviewing collateral requirements will need to be developed.5 Similarly, a credible 
mechanism  to  record  movable  assets  that  can  serve  to  meet  strict  collateral  requirements  will 
need  to  be  provided.  The  use  of  information  and  communication  technology  (ICT)  innovations 
reduces  transaction  costs  for  financing,  which  opens  up  new  markets  for  MSME  products  and 
services, and better targets MSMEs, especially in geographically dispersed islands. Furthermore, 
the  Maldives  faces  significant  energy  challenges  since  imported  diesel  meets  nearly  80%  of  its 
energy requirements.6  
 
8. 
Lessons.  As  recommended  by  the  Independent  Evaluation  Department’s  country 
assistance  program  evaluation,7 continued  engagement  with  a  sector  and  a  long-term  focus  will 
enable  better  policy  dialogue,  improve  sector  outcome,  and  increase  development  impact.  The 
PSDP is a pilot project that could not cover some areas (e.g., establishment of the STR due to the 
limited  resource  envelope  and  providing  sufficient  time  for  the  STR  project  feasibility  study). 
Accordingly,  although  the  PSDP  has  been  successful  within  its  limited  scope  and  resources, 
further  support  is  essential  for  continued  and  sustainable  credit  delivery.  To  bolster  project 
delivery, any further assistance should be provided in a phased manner and should address both 
the  supply  and  demand  sides  of  MSME  development.  The  assistance  should  also  focus  on 
delivering the elements of the MSME Act that the government has submitted to Parliament. The 
Maldives country  partnership  strategy (CPS),  2007–2011  followed  a sequential  approach  of  first

enabling environment for private sector development; and thereafter, resuming investment lending 
in  the  CPS  priority  sectors  of  energy,  transport,  and  MSME  development.8 The  project  is  fully 
aligned  with  CPS  and  the  objectives  of  ADB’s  Financial  Sector  Operational  Plan  and  has  been 
closely coordinating with the development partners.9  
 
9. 
Work  under  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  indicated  that  the  major 
constraints identified at the launch of the PSDP had been largely addressed.10 However, there is 
an unfinished agenda from the PSDP in terms of setting up the STR, creating a credit guarantee 
scheme,  extending  BDS  across  the  country,  and  increasing  credit  lending  under  the  LCF.  The 
proposed  project  will  focus  on  financial  inclusion;  hence,  it  is  important  to  extend  the  coverage 
and  the  outreach  of  the  PSDP  in  solving  MSME  issues  such  as  limited  market  access,  lack  of 
internal  capacity,  and  the  high  cost  of  financing,  transportation,  and  power.  Some  key  lessons 
from  the  PSDP  include  the  need  for  (i)  continued  institutional  strengthening,  (ii) market-oriented 
skills  development  for  MSMEs,  (iii)  sustainability  of  the  initiatives  taken  under  the  PSDP,  (iv) a 
strong and independent project management unit, and (v) an organizational change management 
process involving stakeholders. These lessons are embedded in the project design. 
 
B.  
 
The impact will be a more inclusive and broad-based MSME sector. The outcome will be a 
10. 
further expanded and strengthened MSME sector. For this purpose, the project will strengthen the 
business  environment  and  support  infrastructure  for  doing  business  with  better  knowledge, 
greater access to financing, and expanded business opportunities for MSMEs.

Output 2: Business development service centers and business incubator programs 
strengthened. The project will strengthen the capacity of the BDSC network, broaden the range 
of products and services offered, improve the capacity of BDSCs to better serve business needs 
of  MSMEs,  and  increase  BDSC  operational  performance  and  business  profitability.  Two  BDSC-

selected  MSMEs  under  business  partnership  agreements.  MSME  selection  will  be  based  on

14. 
Output  3:  Credit  guarantee  scheme  initiated.  A  consultancy  will  be  provided  for  (i) 
designing  and  making  credit  guarantee  schemes  operational  toward  reducing  the  collateral 
requirement  for  MSMEs,  (ii)  initiating  a  credit  guarantee  fund  to  diminish  the  risk  incurred  by 
lenders  and  ease  access  to  credit  for  MSMEs  without  sufficient  collateral  to  meet  bank 
requirements; and (iii) undertaking a public awareness campaign to explain the key features of the 
fund.  Following  a  preparatory  consultancy,  the  fund  will  start  with  the  capital  contributed  by  the 
government, and a new entity will be established to manage the fund.  
 

2.    Component 2: Access to Finance Improved (Supply Side) 

 
15. 
Component 2 will improve MSME access to finance by (i) adding to the LCF to meet the 
huge  credit  demand  from  MSMEs,  (ii)  extending  the  CIB  to  improve  information  quality  and 
reduce credit risk, and (iii) establishing an STR database on fixed and movable assets.  
 
16.   Output 1: Line-of-credit facility expanded. An additional LCF of $8.5 million will be built 
with feedback from MED and BML on the implementation of the pilot LCF, which was set up under 
the PSDP to promote a culture of lending to MSMEs with less restrictive collateral requirements 
and  cash-flow-based  financing.13 Of  this,  $1.5  million  will  be financed  by  ADB  and  $7  million  by 
the Islamic Development Bank (IDB). The government will relend the $1.5 million to BML through 
a  subsidiary loan agreement,  detailing the  terms  and conditions  of  onlending  by BML to  eligible 
MSMEs  according      to      the      eligibility      criteria14     mutually      agreed      by      ADB      and      the 
government.15 The loan term will  not  exceed 15  years, including  a  3-year grace period, with the

Economic and Financial 

A. 
 
As  noted  in  the  Maldives  country  partnership  strategy  (footnote  8),  capacity  constraints 
25. 
severely affect the optimal use of externally assisted projects. Due to lack of experience by project 
implementation  units,  some  projects  are  completed  with  delays  of  3–4  years,  undermining  their 
development  effectiveness.  Against  this  background,  three  PMUs  were  established  under  the 
PSDP. Their performance was satisfactory and they played an integral part toward the successful 
implementation  of  government  projects.  Accordingly,  PMUs  will  be  set  up  at  MED,  MMA,  and 
BML, and their project directors will be assisted by consultants. 
 
B. 
 
26. 
Based  on  the  economic  analysis,  the  project  is  expected  to  have  several  economic 
benefits: (i) $5 million increment in the gross domestic product (GDP) by 2016 as local sourcing of 
economic  activity  gains  from  broader  access  to  credit,  (ii) a  more  positive  balance  of  payments 
through an assumed 10% increase in exports and 20% reduction in imports, (iii) tax revenues of 
approximately  $2.4  million,  (iv)  minimum  $12  million  of  add-back  to  GDP  through  a  reduction  in 
nonperforming  assets,  and  (v)  $15  million  incremental  turnover  in  the  MSME  sector.  Other 
economic  benefits  include  lower  government  payroll  expenditure  as  MSMEs  generate  jobs, 
increased lending appetite of banks and additional funds available for credit, and a robust finance 
sector  with  better  credit  judgment  resulting  from  access  to  information  through  the  CIB  and 
establishment of the STR.  
 
27. 
A financial analysis was carried out in accordance with ADB guidelines. All financial costs 
and benefits have been expressed in nominal terms. Cost streams used to determine the financial 
internal rate of return (i.e., capital investment, and operation and maintenance) reflects the cost of 
delivering  the  estimated  benefits.26 Besides  the  returns  expected  from  the  CIB  as  a  result  of 
expanded  membership  and  increased  sale  of  reports,  interest  income  owing  to  fewer 
nonperforming assets and interest savings owing to less foreign debt have been included in the 
revenue stream.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  of  nearly  12%  compares  favorably  with  the 
standard  cost  of  capital  of  slightly  above  4%,  indicating  substantive  financial  viability  for  the 
project. Nonquantifiable financial  benefits, increased capacity  of MSMEs,  better  access to credit 
information, and other related benefits are not included.  
 
C. 
 
28.

finding  mission  in October  2011,  indicates  that MOFT  and the  three implementing  agencies can 
manage loan  proceeds  during  project  implementation.  The  PMUs  at  the  implementing  agencies 
have experience in financial management and procurement in accordance with ADB requirements,

D. 
 
The  project  will  target  population  groups  across  the  country  and  will  lead  to  the 
29. 
development  of  new  and  existing  MSMEs,  thereby  generating  jobs,  particularly  among  women 
and the youth. The services provided by the BDSCs are aimed at increasing the competitiveness 
of MSMEs and supporting export promotion.  
 
30. 
To ensure gender mainstreaming, the project will support interventions designed to boost 
entrepreneurship  and  build marketable  skills for women and  the  youth. Interventions  will  include 
public  awareness,  capacity  building  and  training,  research  and  studies  for  gender  issues,  and 
priority in accessing business development services. A gender action plan will be implemented to 
ensure  inclusiveness  in  the  project  and  to  meet  the  unique  needs  of  women  and  vulnerable 
groups,  the  views  of  which  will  be  solicited  with  respect  to  any  proposed  legislation  or  legal 
amendments. The use of temporary special measures to increase women’s participation in MSME 
development will be encouraged. By supporting less-developed areas of the country, the project 
will help minimize geographical inequality and contribute to balanced regional development, and 
ultimately contribute to improving the Gini coefficient.
